_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Cloverleaf Cold Storage facility located in Chillicothe, Missouri provides cold and frozen including the storage and distribution of nonhazardous packaged foods. We are proud of our safety record and strive to ensure that we design and operate our facility so that hazards are minimized and risks controlled.

We use a refrigeration process to maintain appropriate temperatures at critical control points in our
operation. Anhydrous ammonia, the refrigerant used in this process, is regulated by EPA under 40CFR part
68 and by OSHA under 29CFR 1910.119. We have specific programs and practices in place for controlling this
process to help ensure that a harmful release of ammonia does not occur. These programs and practices
include:
- Use of recognized good engineering practices in the design, installation and operation of our refrigeration
equipment and ensuring this equipment meets applicable codes and standards.
- Continual assessment of hazards and safeguards in our process, in order to reduce risks.
- Use of release prevention practices that have been recognized as effective by Federal and State experts.
- Maintaining preparedness for responding to any emergency that may occur. Using EPA-approved methods and technology, we have analyzed worst-case and alternative scenarios for the unlikely release of ammonia from our Refrigeration Process. The results of these analyses, including any public or environmental receptors are available upon request to facility management and/or from the US EPA.
Our release prevention program focuses on preventing hazardous releases of anhydrous ammonia. Our
equipment and management practices are consistent with OSHA regulations and recognized good
engineering practices specified by ASHRAE, ASME and ASTM standards. In the unlikely event that a release of
ammonia were to occur, monitoring devices would immediately alert us so that quick action can be taken to
minimize the impact. 

We are continually seeking ways to improve the safety of

our operations. Consistent with that policy, our
facility has been designed to include best practices in safety and environmental protection advancements. As
evidence of this commitment, we completed a process hazard analysis in April 2009 and expect to
resolve all recommendations from that analysis by the end of 2010. Our Process Safety and Risk
Management Procedures and Emergency Response Plan are in place and being used to manage hazards and
control risks associated with hazardous materials at our facility, including annual reviews of operating
procedures. We continually monitor our operations to identify ways to maintain a leadership position within our industry in environmental, health and safety practices.
